title: Liu Dai
text:
Liu Dai (died 192), <a href="courtesy%20name">courtesy name</a> Gongshan, was a Chinese politician who lived during the late <a href="Eastern%20Han%20dynasty">Eastern Han dynasty</a> of China.
Life.
Liu Dai was from Mouping County (牟平縣), <a href="Donglai%20Commandery">Donglai Commandery</a> (東萊郡), which is in present-day <a href="Muping%20District">Muping District</a>, <a href="Yantai">Yantai</a>, <a href="Shandong">Shandong</a>. He served as a Palace Attendant (侍中) and the Inspector of <a href="Yan%20Province">Yan Province</a> (兗州刺史) under the Han dynasty.
In the spring of 190, Liu Dai joined the <a href="Campaign%20against%20Dong%20Zhuo">coalition</a> of warlords led by <a href="Yuan%20Shao">Yuan Shao</a> to oppose <a href="Dong%20Zhuo">Dong Zhuo</a>, a tyrannical warlord who controlled the central government and held <a href="Emperor%20Xian%20of%20Han">Emperor Xian</a> hostage. Later Liu Dai had disagreements with <a href="Qiao%20Mao">Qiao Mao</a>, the Administrator of <a href="Dong%20Commandery">Dong Commandery</a>, so he killed Qiao Mao and replaced him with Wang Gong (王肱).
Liu Dai then arranged for marriages between his family and the clans of Yuan Shao and <a href="Gongsun%20Zan">Gongsun Zan</a>. Yuan Shao allowed his family members to stay with Liu Dai, while Gongsun Zan sent his follower Fan Fang (范方) to lead troops to support Liu Dai. When Yuan Shao later developed a rivalry with Gongsun Zan, the latter broke off relations with Liu Dai as well. Gongsun Zan said to Fan Fang, "If Liu Dai does not drive away Yuan Shao's family members, you will lead your men back to our territory. I'll attack Liu Dai after I've eliminated Yuan Shao." Liu Dai was at a loss over how to handle the crisis when his adviser Wang Yu (王彧) told him to consult <a href="Cheng%20Yu">Cheng Yu</a>, and Liu Dai heeded his suggestion. Cheng Yu urged Liu Dai to stand on Yuan Shao's side and Liu followed the advice. Gongsun Zan was defeated and conquered by Yuan Shao eventually.
In 192, thousands of former <a href="Yellow%20Turban%20Rebellion">Yellow Turban rebels</a> from <a href="Qing%20Province">Qing Province</a> swarmed into Yan Province and gathered in <a href="Dongping%20County">Dongping County</a>. Liu Dai wanted to attack the rebels but <a href="Bao%20Xin">Bao Xin</a> advised him against it. Liu Dai ignored Bao Xin and proceeded to attack the Yellow Turbans, and was defeated and killed in battle.
In "Romance of the Three Kingdoms".
In the 14th-century historical novel "<a href="Romance%20of%20the%20Three%20Kingdoms">Romance of the Three Kingdoms</a>", when Yan Province was conquered by the warlord <a href="Cao%20Cao">Cao Cao</a>, Liu Dai had no choice but to surrender. After losing his domain, he attacked <a href="Liu%20Bei">Liu Bei</a>, but was defeated and robbed of his position. Liu Dai followed his adviser <a href="Bao%20Xin">Bao Xin</a>'s suggestion to join Cao Cao and had since been engaged in suppressing the Yellow Turban remnants. As his achievements increased, Liu Dai became more overconfident and he refused to listen to Bao Xin, which resulted in their deaths.
